areaDesc.3: Close to center of city - all city conveniences - adequate transportation - parking area.
areaDesc.4: Age of properties - surroundings - hospital in area
areaDesc.14: Montford Avenue at one time was one of the best residential streets in the city and there are many large, beautiful homes occupied by very substantial citizens.  Pearson Drive also has many, expensive homes.  The trend, however, is not in this direction and while the area is still a very desirable place in which to live, the increasing age of the properties and encroachment into immediate adjoining areas of lower income group will eventually have a detrimental effect in this area.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: School in area - all city convenience except gas.
areaDesc.4: Outside city limits - inadequate transportation - no restrictions.  Industrial plants located in area.

g.1: Slowly due to increased industrial activity

areaDesc.14: Industrial plants in the area employ practically all people living in it and their activity (uncertain with exception of the National Casket Company) governs activity in the area.  Majority of houses built when furniture factory established.  It has since closed and is now operated at intervals by the Alden Manufaturing Company (somewhat unstable) which manufactures an imitation antiwue furniture.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

areaDesc.3: All city convenience - Golf Course - Mountain View - Swimming Pool - Lake - Adequate Bus Transportation.  Originally highly restricted.
areaDesc.4: About 85% undeveloped and several hundred vacant lots as well as adjoining acreage, golf course, lake and swimming pool are owned by holding company for defunct mortgage company which acquired property by foreclosure.  Sales program on vacant lots now getting under way but considerable speculation as to restrictions which will appear under the new program.

5.a: Executives and business men and Professional men.

areaDesc.13: Problematic - If restrictions are enforced as originally set out, trend of desirability will be upward.
areaDesc.14: Information is that holding company has offered lake to city free, subject to conditions that city would maintain water at certain level in lake,etc., but offer has been withdrawn.  Abandonment of lake or its destruction will seriously affect values and desirability of this area.  The opinion was expressed that abandonment of lake would affect desirability of section and cause values to decline and likewise would lower tax assessments and for this reason lake would be maintained even though it was necessary for city to take it over.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative, and Hugh G. Hall, HOLC, Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences, adequate transportation close to community business center - schools - churches.  Only short distance to Beaver Lake Swimming Pool and Golf Course.
areaDesc.4: Encroachment of Tourist homes along Merriman Avenue, which is just East of the area.
areaDesc.14: That part North of Edgewood is best part of area.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences, adequate transportation, close to main business section, schools, churches, etc.
areaDesc.4: Merriman Avenue heavy traffic artery.  Encroachment of Tourist Homes and apartments.  Tuberculosis sanitarium on Bernard Avenue, Hospital on Woodfin.  Older type of properties. Boarding and Rooming houses in area.

5.e: Negro slowly in area, around Crescent, Madison and Lee Streets.

6.a: Large and small singles, Duplexes - Apartments

9.b: Large homes for use as tourist homes

10.b: Apartment - small singles, large singles for tourist purposes

areaDesc.14: Along Merriman Avenue some large, expensive homes still occupied by owners, but great majority being turned into Tourist Homes by owners to increase income, or being purchased by others for this purpose.  Montford Avenue, formerly one of best residential streets in city.  Flint and Cumberland also good residential streets, but boarding and rooming houses are gradually encroaching.  Good negro section on Crescent, Madison and Lee, ten years ago occupied entirely by whites.  Also lower type negro section on Short Street and at North end of Flint St.  Business gradually expanding into this area on most every side of present main business district.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

areaDesc.3: Adjoins Asheville Country Club & Golf Course - Grove Park Inn, famous as one of the leading resort hotels in the country - Magnificent mountain view - Schools in area - adequate transportation - all city conveniences.  Parkways in middle of streets and grass plots on sidewalks maintained by "Grove Park" Park Commision with property owners assessed 10 cents per front foot for this maintenance.  Recognized as the most ideal spot around Asheville for the average business or professional man to reside.
areaDesc.4: None

5.a: Business Executives - Professional men and Capitalists

6.a: Large singles - a few higher-price apartments and duplexes

areaDesc.14: Southern part of area South and East of Golf Links is known as "Grove Park" and is about 90% built up with beautiful expensive homes predominating.  This part of the area is the older part but is still "tops".  The part of the area West of the Golf Links and Kimberly Avenue contains the lower prices properties.  All new construction is in that part of the area lying North of the Golf Links, this being the part more recently developed.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative, and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city convenience - adequate transportation - close to schools - churches and main business section.
areaDesc.4: On eastern side of area, (which is the foot of Sunset Mountain) are some obsolete tubercular sanitariums.  However, these buildings are gradually being razed and it will only be a short time until all are removed.

6.a: Small singles- some apartments and duplexes.

areaDesc.14: Area not restricted- general in type of property and development.  Good, bad and indifferent houses all over area.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.2: Rolling to mountainous on Western side and Eastern side.
areaDesc.3: Schools - churches in area - all city conveniences - Adequate transportation.
areaDesc.4: Industrial plants along railroad tracks on western side of area.  Cheap construction, also filling stations and some cheap stores on Biltmore Road.  Also many business places in the part nearest main business district.
areaDesc.14: North end of Western side almost a mountain.  Southern side contains railroad depot, big negro bus district, and cheap houses. Eastern side very rolling.  Better part is that nearest Main Business District.

15.1: William Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences, adequate transportation.  Biltmore business center in area.  Schools and churches, also in area
areaDesc.4: Railroad and River through northern part - large portion outside city limits.  Industrial plants in Northern part of area.  Subject to overflow in section close to railroad and Swannanoe River.  Sanitarium of Biltmore Road in extreme Northern part of area.

5.a: Bleachery workers - clerical mechanics - Railroad workers

areaDesc.14: Biltmore Station on Southern Railroad through northern part of this area was originally built by the Vanderbilts and around the station was built a business center, English Type, and many small English type pebble dash houses, 5 to 7 rooms, 1.5 to 2 story.  It was the entrance to the Vanderbilt Estate and something of a lobby, but the trend is definitely downward.  Across the Hendersonville Road, at the southwest corner of this area, is located Biltmore-Forrest Estates, which is a highly restricted subdivision.

15.1: William Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences - close to schools and colleges.
areaDesc.4: Railroad yards and roundhouses on Southwest - Inadequate transportation.  No restrictions.
areaDesc.14: This area contains about a dozen houses, all large single family and expensive and misplaced.  Future development, if any, will probably be in the medium to lower priced range.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences - close to schools, churches and business center.  Adequate transportation.
areaDesc.4: Negro settlement in area - Sanitarium for those suffering nervous ailment, located on Caledonia Road (formerly Kenilworth Inn).  Smoke from railroad.

5.a: Professional men - Business men - Clerical - Railroad employees

areaDesc.13: Northern part upward - Southern part static to downward.
areaDesc.14: Southern part of this area is known as "Old Kenilworth" and is about 80% developed.  Northern part is known as Kenilworth addition and Fountainblead and is only about 10% developed.  Central Western portion is known as Forest Hills.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.2: Part in Valley - Mountainous on all sides.
areaDesc.3: City conveniences
areaDesc.4: Location built around old brick yard.  Unpaved streets.  Transportation inadequate.
areaDesc.13: Almost bottom now - litle prospect for any better.
areaDesc.14: This is a very cheap negro section all but North end being in valley.  Mountains in East, West and South on which white people live.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

areaDesc.3: Highly restricted residential area and restrictions strongly enforced.  All city convenience except gas.  Private country club with golf course located in area.  All residences are in higher-priced class.  Private bus transportation.
areaDesc.4: None except the fact that the Eastern side of Hendersonville Road is not restricted and there are small stores and tourist cabins located on that side, which adversely affects properties fronting on Western side of road.

c.1: None except the fact that the Eastern side of Hendersonville Road is not restricted and there are small stores and tourist cabins located on that side, which adversely affects properties fronting on Western side of road.

areaDesc.14: That part of the area lying along Hendersonville Road, White Oak Road and Buena Vista Road contains the lower priced properties.  The remainder of this area contains nothing but higher priced properties.  It is an exclusive development joined on the North, West and South by the Baltimore Estate, former home of George W. Vanderbilt, deceased, containing 12,000 acres and the famous Baltimore House.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences - churches, schools, in area.  Adequate transportation on Haywood Road, which is almost in center of area.  Private bus line operates to Enka Corporation Plant about three miles from this area.
areaDesc.4: Distance to main business center not in line of future better development.  Large number of homes owned by lending agencies through foreclosure and other acquisition.  Hosiery mill in area.

5.a: Clerical - skilled mechanics.  Laborers and Industrial and Mill workers of Enka Corp.

6.a: Small singles - Some duplexes and apartments

areaDesc.14: This is what was formerly West Asheville, a separate incorporation.  It is necessary to cross River to get to it and Haywood Road is about the center of the area and along it, for approximately 1.5 miles, are many business places, from cheap to good, with centers at Haywood and Westwood and at Brevard Road and Haywood Road.  Very little development in extreme Western part.  Eastern boundary of area is a high bluff with river at bottom and on this side, north of Haywood Road, is some very, very cheap development.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative.

areaDesc.3: Adjoining Golf Course - near Asheville School for Boys - All city conveniences except gas - Highly restricted subdivision.
areaDesc.4: Holding Company for defunct mortgage company owns most vacant lots and adjoining acreage and possibility of future development not being in line with present type of properties.  Somewhat isolated distance to schools and main business section.  Inadequate transportation.  Tourist camp on Haywood Road near Northwest corner.

9.b: Nothing for sale except vacant lots and no demand for them

areaDesc.13: Problematical - depending to a large extent on practice followed in disposing of vacant lots and what restrictions are maintained.
areaDesc.14: The subdivision originally started by founder of Asheville School for Boys (an exclusive institution) with the idea in mind of selling the sites to former students for use as summer homes.  Ownership originally carried with it right to use school lake and golf course.  However, after spending his money he found it necessary to borrow to further the development and mortgage company foreclosed and now owns practically all of vacant property.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences - Adequate transportation - not far distant to  school - Asheville Rhododendron Gardens adjoins Southern part of area.
areaDesc.4: Southern part of area slightly isolated and distant from school and community business facilities.

6.c: 20 years on Vermont & Brevard - 10 more years on southern part.
6.a: Small singles - some apartments and duplexes

areaDesc.13: Northern part static - Southern part upward
areaDesc.14: Vermont & Northern part of Brevard almost entirely downward.  Southern part only about 10% built up.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences - Restricted residential sections - Adequate transportation - close to schools, churches and business center.
areaDesc.4: Some distance to main business section - approach from East not good.

5.a: Executives of Enka Corporation, some business and professional men

areaDesc.14: Along Heywood Road are several higher priced residences, and in other part of area construction is fairly uniform.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city conveniences except gas.  Negro churches and schools in area.  South end has adequate transportation.
areaDesc.4: North end inadequate transportation.  Unpaved streets.  Quite a few foreclosed properties owned by lending agencies.

5.a: Common laborers and tannery workers and negro railroad laborers.

areaDesc.14: Some properties of uniform construction built in this area by white owners for investment purposes.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative

areaDesc.3: City conveniences - paved streets - schools close by - scenic view.
areaDesc.4: No transportation - distance to business section, churches, etc., Heavy foreclosures - vandalism worst in city.
areaDesc.14: Started off with some good houses but then dropped and low class of people started moving in.  Jerry built houses were started and gradually forced better class of people out.  Intimated that some bootleggers resided in the area.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Supervisor

areaDesc.3: High School in area - All city conveniences - Adequate transportation.
areaDesc.4: Surrounded by cheap construction - area about 90% developed.
areaDesc.14: This is a fairly uniform section, small but decidedly superior to the surrounding areas.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.

areaDesc.3: All city convenience - Restricted residential section - adequate transportation close by - not far distant to schools, churches and business center.
areaDesc.4: Nothing particular.

5.a: Business men - professional men, clerks - railroad men

areaDesc.14: This is a small section of uniform construction, much better than the surrounding area.

15.1: Wm. Coleman, Loan Service Field Representative and Hugh C. Hall, HOLC Fee Property Appraiser.
